news.title: The Millennial Manifesto
news.text:
An amazing 8,000-word essay entitled The Lost Generation surfaced Monday in Compact Magazine by Jacob Savage, and is one of the most illuminating pieces I've read in years. I'm 59-years-old. I'm at the very front edge of the Gen X'ers, but I identify as a Baby Boomer. I missed the cut-off by about two years. I fully recognize that every generation, by the time they get to my advanced years, begins telling stories about how the generation following them just aren't the same as they were when they were growing up. With Millennials, I've discovered that this generational axiom has the added benefit of being true. Millennials have become the punchline of a lot of jokes. The rap on these current 28-44-year-olds are that they're lazier than the generation before them, not too motivated to make their own way in the world, very self-centered, and generally gloomy about what the future holds for them. My son is 35-years-old, right in the heart of this cohort of Americans, and just provided me with a year's worth of stand-up material with his pre-Thanksgiving trip to see me alone.After reading this Savage article, complete with tons of stats and anecdotes accumulated from tons of first-person interviews, I now understand why Millennials in general are the way they are. And there is a ton of opportunity for J.D. Vance in 2028, assuming he's the Republican nominee after Secretary of State Marco Rubio all but cleared the field. The article is about the incredible damage DEI policies have had on the employment prospects, and the resulting psychological impact, on Millennial white males trying to make their mark writing in the world of media. It's obviously a niche industry, but it's a microcosm of the ongoing devastation of DEI policies that took root during the Obama presidency and crescendoed after the death of George Floyd in 2020. Savage, a fledgling writer trying to break through writing television pilots and pitching them to studios to turn into series, tells this story. 

But of course, by 2016, we were already too late. The showrunner emailed us back apologetically. â€œI had initially thought I might be able to bring you guys on,â€ he wrote, â€œbut in the end it wasnâ€™t possible.â€ We met with the executive anywayâ€”a Gen-X white guyâ€”who told us how much he loved our pilot. But the writers room was small, he explained apologetically, and the higher-level writers were all white men. They couldnâ€™t have an all-white-male room. Maybe, if the show got another season, theyâ€™d be able to bring us on. They never did. The doors seemed to close everywhere and all at once. In 2011, the year I moved to Los Angeles, white men were 48 percent of lower-level TV writers; by 2024, they accounted for just 11.9 percent. The Atlanticâ€™s editorial staff went from 53 percent male and 89 percent white in 2013 to 36 percent male and 66 percent white in 2024. White men fell from 39 percent of tenure-track positions in the humanities at Harvard in 2014 to 18 percent in 2023. In retrospect, 2014 was the hinge, the year DEI became institutionalized across American life.

Before you dismiss this as a lefty writer complaining that DEI policies he probably supported backfiring on him, this is a much, much bigger story than this one job market. Countless white males coming out of college or high school in the mid-10's, regardless of their political ideology, if they held any ideology at all, ran into a brick wall where career opportunities, and ultimately their chance at the American dream, were taken away from them for the sake of diversity hires. In 1974's Blazing Saddles, there was a scene where the railroad workers were brought in to cut a deal with the all-white residents of Rock Ridge to build a fake city in order to thwart the evil Hedley Lamarr, played by Harvey Korman. I'll clean up the language to make it FCC-compliant, but the offer by the townfolk was, "All right, we'll give land to the Blacks and the Asians, but we don't want the Irish." That wasn't an acceptable deal, and finally, everybody was included in the opportunity of a stake of land. That's what's happening here, except the Democrats who implemented DEI policies across education, law enforcement, law, and much of corporate America, still don't want the Irish. Whites need not apply. 

This may be how Boomer and Gen-X white men experienced DEI. But for white male millennials, DEI wasnâ€™t a gentle rebalancingâ€”it was a profound shift in how power and prestige were distributed. Yet practically none of the thousands of articles and think-pieces about diversity have considered the issue by cohort. This isnâ€™t a story about all white men. Itâ€™s a story about white male millennials in professional America, about those who stayed, and who (mostly) stayed quiet. The same identity, a decade apart, meant entirely different professional fates. If you were forty in 2014â€”born in 1974, beginning your career in the late-90sâ€”you were already established. If you were thirty in 2014, you hit the wall.

To those of us on the right, DEI was an issue that became a political bludgeon for Donald Trump, and as president, signed two executive orders to end wasteful DEI programs and preferences in government agencies, and another one to end illegal discrimination based on race and restroring merit-based opportunities in states and entities like colleges and universities that receive federal funding. It was a principled fight that Donald Trump campaigned on, and it was a promise on which he delivered. DEI certainly hit its peak in 2020 after George Floyd, but is sadly still far too entrenched in way too many sectors of the economy. What I failed to understand is not just what discrimination it did to conservatives trying to make their way in the world, but what it has done to disillusion 30-something males who might otherwise be liberals, but not so much anymore. From the tail end of Savage's piece, which I would recommend you read every word and share it with others: 

Most of the men I interviewed started out as liberals. Some still are. But to feel the weight of societyâ€™s disfavor can be disorienting. We millennials were true believers in race and gender-blind meritocracy, which for all its faultsâ€”its naÃ¯vetÃ© about human nature, its optimism in the American Dreamâ€”was far superior to what replaced it. And to see that vision so spectacularly betrayed has engendered a skepticism toward the entire liberal project that won't soon disappear. â€œWhat troubles me is that a lot of thriving white millennial men have had to follow the Josh Hawley path, where you have to leave liberal America,â€ an old friend, the father of two biracial children, told me. â€œI don't want to do that. Liberal America is my home. But if everyone says, this is not the place for you, what are you supposed to do?â€

Most of the men he interviewed started out as liberals. Some still are. My gracious, but what an opportunity that provides to expand the base. Donald Trump made huge inroads with labor union workers, with Blacks, Hispanics, surburban women, lots of voting blocs that typically vote Democratic, but got very turned off by Joe Biden's regency and Kamala Harris' ridiculous 107-day word salad tour. Inflation was killing them, and there was no one else to blame but Biden-Harris policies. And Trump, X and Truth Social warts and all, at least demonstrated he could generate a pretty prosperous economy the first time around, so he was the better choice in 2024. In all likelihood, Vice-President Vance is going to be the nominee. Secretary Rubio told Vanity Fair he's not running in 2028, and outside of a possible run by Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, the field is pretty open for Vance to get the nomination without too much trouble. On the Democratic side of the aisle, a knife fight is developing that should be hugely entertaining to watch. Former Transportation Secretary, Pothole Pete Buttigieg, wants a shot. Former Hillary Clinton and Obama senior staffer Rahm Emmanuel is going to get in. Gavin Newsom is running, both away from California and for the White House. There will be others. And as I wrote about earlier in the week, Axios is reporting that Kamala Harris is definitely gearing up for another run. Polling shows that among the Democratic potential contenders, Harris has a 11-point lead over her closest rival, Gavin Newsom. If the general election in November of 2028 turns into a Vance V. Harris contest, it will literally be a Millennial white male with the ability to articulate and communicate policies, and a vision for the future in a way the Republican Party hasn't seen since...ever. Ronald Reagan could communicate, he certainly had a vision for the future, but he wasn't in the age cohort of a field of voters Millennials make up that are currently available for harvest. Who would Vance be running against? Kamala Harris, who is literally and figuratively the embodiment of a DEI hire. She was chosen by Joe Biden to fulfill a promise of picking a Black female as his number two. Harris was not a merit-based pick. She was picked because she was thought by the Biden team to be the Black female that would do them the least harm. And she failed to cross even that low bar.

Job number one for whomever is running nationally for the Republicans, whether it's a Senate or House candidate in the midterms, or anyone running for the White House in '28, is to talk about the economy and affordability, and counter the narrative media and Democrats are spinning that we're in the worst economic environment ever becuase of Trump policies. Trump spoke to the nation Wednesday night and reeled off facts about job growth, lower energy costs, and how the housing market is improving now that illegal immigration is no longer creating an artificially high demand for units, driving up prices. All that is very good. But there's more that the next Republican for president, presumably Vance, needs to add to the agenda. The disillusionment on the left after what they believed in failed them makes these Millennial white males willing to listen, if Vance can resonate how the best way to achieve the equality they really want is equal access to opportunity, not government and corporations picking winners and losers based on skin color or gender in order to achieve equity. Replace the lost opportunies with words and actions to expand opportunities will reap electoral benefits to such a degree that Democrats won't know what hit them on Election Night. The Late Charlie Kirk used to be very, very good at that messaging to college-aged kids all over the country. He may have been the best in the conservative movement ever to be able to reason with young people, but a close second is Vance. When he spoke at a TPUSA event at Ole Miss a couple days before Halloween, it was a masterclass performance. The big question is will Vance, or someone around him, show him this Savage article, and will Vance grasp the political upside available to him and the skill set for communication he possesses? The good news is yes, he does. 

A lot of people think "DEI" is lame diversity seminars or racial slogans at NFL games. In reality, it was a deliberate program of discrimination primarily against white men. This is an incredible piece that describes the evil of DEI and its consequences:https://t.co/fMiIfvz0qzâ€” JD Vance (@JDVance) December 17, 2025

There are lots of doomsayers on the right who think Republicans are headed for disaster in the midterms unless they get back to talking about the core issues of economics and affordability. That certainly needs to be the primary message. But there are millions of potential voters out there that the Democratic Party kicked to the curb who are persuadable, if somone just gives them attention, an ear, understanding, and most of all, hope for the future.

Rob Reiner, actor, director, writer, producer and actor, and his wife, Michele Singer Reiner, were found murdered in their home on Sunday, Dec. 14, 2025. The This Is Spinal Tap creator was 78. Singer Reiner was 68. Their son, Nick Reiner, was questioned and later arrested and charged with their slayings.

Hereâ€™s everything we know so far about the tragic loss of one of Americaâ€™s most beloved filmmakers.

ğŸ¬ SIGN UP for Paradeâ€™s Daily newsletter to get the latest pop culture news & celebrity interviews delivered right to your inbox ğŸ¬

What happened to Rob Reiner?

Rob Reiner and Michele Singer Reiner were found dead in their mansion in the Brentwood area of Los Angeles on Sunday, Dec. 14, 2025.

The family said in a statement shortly after the news broke, â€œIt is with profound sorrow that we announce the tragic passing of Michele and Rob Reiner. We are heartbroken by this sudden loss, and we ask for privacy during this unbelievably difficult time.â€

TMZ reported that their bodies were â€œbutcheredâ€ and that sources described the scene as being the crimes of a â€œmad man.â€

The New York Times reported that investigators are still trying to determine the time of death, and that the Reiners may have been killed on Saturday, Dec. 13, 2025, or in the very early hours on Sunday.

TMZ reported that when the Reinersâ€™ bodies were discovered, rigor mortis had already set in, which usually begins between two and six hours after death.

Related: We Ranked Every Rob Reiner Movieâ€”Hereâ€™s the One Thatâ€™s Still a Perfect 10

Who found Rob Reiner and his wife Michele Singer?

According to PEOPLE, Rob and Micheleâ€™s daughter Romy Reiner found her parents after they were murdered.

More details emerged in a report from the New York Times, which revealed that a massage therapist who was scheduled to be at the house called Romy when she couldnâ€™t get in. Romy then went to the Reinersâ€™ family home, where she found her fatherâ€™s body. She immediately left the premises and reportedly didnâ€™t know her mother was also dead inside. She called police, then family friend Billy Crystal, who lived close by and came over to say a final farewell to his longtime collaborator and Michele.

On Wednesday, Dec. 17, 2025, Romy and her brother Jake Reiner released a statement about the slayings.

â€œWords cannot even begin to describe the unimaginable pain we are experiencing every moment of the day,â€ they said. â€œThe horrific and devastating loss of our parents, Rob and Michele Reiner, is something that no one should ever experience. They werenâ€™t just our parents; they were our best friends.â€

They continued, â€œWe are grateful for the outpouring of condolences, kindness, and support we have received not only from family and friends but people from all walks of life. We now ask for respect and privacy, for speculation to be tempered with compassion and humanity, and for our parents to be remembered for the incredible lives they lived and the love they gave.â€

Related: Why Rob Reiner Rejected the Title of â€˜Heroâ€™ Months Before His Death

What time were police called to Rob Reinerâ€™s house?

Multiple reports state that paramedics and police were called to the Reinersâ€™ home between 3:30 p.m. and 3:40 p.m. PT on Sunday, Dec. 14, 2025.

Where did Rob Reiner and Michele Singer live?

The Reiners lived in the wealthy enclave of Brentwood, located in the west side of Los Angeles county.

About 42,000 people reside in the neighborhood, including LeBron James, Gwyneth Paltrow, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Dr. Dre and Disney CEO Bob Iger, as well as former vice president Kamala Harris and former second gentleman Doug Emhoff. Other stars whoâ€™ve lived in Brentwood include Marilyn Monroe, Bea Arthur, Betty White and O.J. Simpson.

Related: Billy Crystal and Larry David Seen at Rob Reinerâ€™s Home After His Death

How did Rob Reiner die?

Both Rob and Michele Singer Reinerâ€™s causes of deaths were homicide: They reportedly died after an assailant slit their throats. TMZ reported that the slayings took place after a â€œheated argumentâ€ with their son Nick and that the bodies showed signs of â€œlacerations consistent with a knife.â€

Prosecutors in the case specified in their formal charging of Nick Reiner that a knife was used to commit the murders.

On Dec. 17, 2025, the Los Angeles County Medical Examinerâ€™s Office released documents stating that the couple died from â€œmultiple sharp force injuries,â€ the New York Post reported. They reportedly suffered from stab wounds to their throats as well as other parts on their bodies.

Related: Ron Howard Mourns Rob Reiner With Powerful Tribute Hours After His Death

Who killed Rob Reiner and his wife?

Nick Reiner, son of Rob Reiner and Michele Singer Reiner, was arrested in connection with their deaths, but is innocent until proven guilty.

Related: Nick Reiner Appears Unhappy in Photo With Parents 3 Months Before Tragedy

Who was the last person to talk to Rob Reiner?

While we donâ€™t know the specific last person who spoke to Rob Reiner before his death, we do know that earlier that day and week, he was with friends and family who loved him.

Monty Python star Eric Idle said he spoke to Rob the day before the director was murdered.

â€œRob Reiner was a lovely man. I spoke to him last night for over an hour,â€ Idle wrote on X (formerly Twitter) just after 1 a.m. PT on Monday, Dec. 15, 2025. â€œI always enjoyed his company. I met him at his Dadâ€™s in 1975. He was telling me about fiming [sic] at Stonehenge and his thoughts for the future. This is so awful. I shall miss him. A clever, talented and very thoughtful man. So awful.â€

Cinematographer Barry Markowitz told Page Six that he was likely one of the last people to see the Reiners alive, as heâ€™d recently been staying with them in their Brentwood home. Markowitz said that the Reiners invited him to stay at their house when he was in town to promote one of his projects in November, and that at the time, it appeared Nick was â€œon the upswingâ€ with his health.

â€œHe looked great. He was sitting and talking with the family,â€ Markowitz recalled. â€œThey eat dinner together, old school, and a lot of love, always a lot of love â€¦ He helped out, he took out the garbage, he watched TV, he washed dishes. Heâ€™d bring me something to drink. He was just normal in that sense.â€

Markowitz said he didnâ€™t notice anything unusual and that the family was loving and normal. When asked about what he thought of Nickâ€™s alleged behavior and if he believed he could murder his own parents, he replied, â€œItâ€™s just a sickness. Thatâ€™s my verdict.â€

Rob, Michele and Nick Reiner all attended pal Conan Oâ€™Brienâ€˜s holiday party on Saturday, Dec. 13, 2025, TMZ reported. The three of them reportedly had a â€œvery loud argumentâ€ at the soiree, after which Rob and Michele went home. Sources claimed that Michele was lamenting to friends that she and Rob were struggling for several months to get Nick treatment for his addiction and mental health problems.

Related: The Chilling Message Rob Reiner Told the World Months Before His Murder

Who is Nick Reiner?

Nick Reiner is the son of Rob Reiner and Michele Singer Reiner. He was a screenwriter and worked with his father on the 2015 film Being Charlie, which was loosely autobiographical. He reportedly periodically Nick lived at home with his parents, and TMZ reported that Nick left the family home on his own accord before the slayings.

At one point, Nick worked as an intern for the long-running Seth Macfarlane animated comedy Family Guy.

â€œHe was an intern on the show Family Guy for around three to six months. His father helped him get the gig,â€ a source told Page Six, adding that Rob â€œwould drop him offâ€ and â€œpick him upâ€ from the job daily. The insider claimed that Nick would work for about four hours a day, but that he did little actual work, instead spending the bulk of his time â€œshooting the s**tâ€ with his colleagues.

â€œHe did not work hard and he wasnâ€™t a hard worker,â€ the insider claimed. â€œHe was 100 percent entitled. There was really no responsibility for him because we didnâ€™t have interns. It was a favor for Rob.â€

The source called Nick â€œcaptivatingâ€ and said he had a dark sense of humor.

â€œHe was a funny kid. He was charismatic in a dark, introverted way. He was a goofy 20-year-old,â€ the insider said. â€œHe was the black sheep. He felt like a f**k up. He knew that. He was self-aware of how his family was doing and how he represented them in a negative space. But none of that felt offensive or scary.â€

â€œHe was coming off rehab, so he was sober,â€ the source added. â€œThis was part of his path to recovery. His whole identity was being sober.â€

In terms of the allegations that Nick murdered his parents, the insider said, â€œI am not that shocked. He is a troubled person. Nick had an aura of darkness around him with his addiction issues. When you have addiction and mental health, there is room for emotional murders â€¦ It doesnâ€™t seem unfounded. He was a troubled kid from a young age and had issues. But thatâ€™s not the Nick I knew.â€

A source told PEOPLE that Nick struggled to find his own identity in the shadow of his famous father and grandfather (Carl Reiner, who died in 2020).

â€œNick wanted to live a life that didnâ€™t exist. He was entitled,â€ the insider said. â€œHe didnâ€™t want to do any work but expected to be loved the way the rest of his family was.â€ The source added that Michele and Rob â€œfelt enormous guilt for so long that they couldnâ€™t help Nick get his life together â€¦ they could never reach stability with Nick. They tried everythingâ€”giving him space, keeping him closeâ€”but his struggles are so deep. Itâ€™s just a parentâ€™s worst nightmare. They were such lovely people and tried in every way to help their son.â€

Related: Does Nick Reiner Have Instagram? See the Private Account His Siblings Follow

What did Nick Reiner suffer from?

Nick struggled with mental illness and addiction for much of his life, TMZ reported which at times left him homeless and often in and out of various rehabilitation centers and programs; his count as of 2016 was reportedly 17 stints. His substance abuse, and his familyâ€™s responses to it, deteriorated his relationship with his parents. Sources alleged to TMZ that prescription drugs especially â€œmessed with [Nickâ€™s] head.â€

â€œI was homeless in Maine. I was homeless in New Jersey. I was homeless in Texas,â€ Nick told PEOPLE in 2016. â€œI spent nights on the street. I spent weeks on the street. It was not fun â€¦ If I wanted to do it my way and not go to the programs they were suggesting, then I had to be homeless.â€

â€œWhen Nick would tell us that it wasnâ€™t working for him, we wouldnâ€™t listen,â€ Rob recalled to the Los Angeles Times in September 2015. â€œWe were desperate, and because the people had diplomas on their wall, we listened to them when we should have been listening to our son.â€

â€œWe were so influenced by these people,â€ Michele added at the time. â€œThey would tell us heâ€™s a liar, that he was trying to manipulate us. And we believed them.â€

For his part, Nick said in a 2016 interview with Build Studios that he â€œdidnâ€™t really bond a lotâ€ with his father when he was young. He also admitted (via the Los Angeles Times), â€œI had no identity, and I had no passions. I think the reason I had no identity was because I have a famous dad and a famous grandpa, and that fame sort of informs who you are. So I wanted to edge out my own identity with a more rebellious, angry, drug-addicted sort of persona.â€

In 2018, Nick revealed that on the Dopey podcast that heâ€™d once gotten so high that he completely trashed his parentsâ€™ guest house.

â€œI got totally spun out on uppers,â€ he said. â€œI think it was coke and something elseâ€”and I was up for days on end. I started punching out different things in my guest house â€¦ started with the TV and then I went over to the lamp â€¦ everything in the guest house got wrecked.â€

In September 2025, Rob told NPR that Nick was doing well and had been sober for about six years at that point in time.

Sources told PEOPLE that at Oâ€™Brienâ€™s holiday party, â€œNick was freaking everyone out, acting crazy, kept asking people if they were famous.â€ According to TMZ, Nick arrived underdressed for the â€œritzyâ€ event (he wore a sweatshirt while everyone else wore suits and fancy dresses). Insiders alleged that he was behaving erratically, roaming around the property aimlessly and barely interacting with other guests. According to NBC News, one of those guests was Barry star and Saturday Night Live alum Bill Hader: Nick reportedly interrupted Hader during what Hader told him was a â€œprivate conversation,â€ then stoood still, stared blankly and finally stormed off.

Sources alleged that Rob and Michele were embarrassed at Nickâ€™s behavior at the party and that theyâ€™d â€œtried everythingâ€ to get their son to be healthy.

â€œThey had had an argument at Conanâ€™s holiday party, and Rob had been telling people that theyâ€™re scared for Nick and scared that his mental state was deteriorating,â€ a source told the New York Post. A friend of the Reiner family claimed that Rob and Michele were urging Nick to get treatment at a facility for a drug relapse, but that he refused.

Markowitz concurred that the Reiners worked extraordinarily hard to get Nick healthy.

â€œThey gave him everything, they tried a million things with him,â€ he told Page Six. â€œNot giving him money but sending him to top-of-the-line places. Rob never gave up. He tried everything. If you knew Rob, he was just a bundle of love.â€ He added that he and Rob never suspected Nick could be violent with them, explaining, â€œ[Rob] never had fears for his safety. Iâ€™m not in his head, but we talked. [Nick] wasnâ€™t a violent type. I slept in the same house as Nick. There was never a thought, I believe, in Robâ€™s head [that Nick was a danger]. If he would have thought his life was in peril at any point, he would have handled the situation.â€ He added, â€œWhen somebody is mentally disturbed, you donâ€™t need a reason. Thereâ€™s no rhyme or reason. Mental illness, thatâ€™s the reason.â€

However, a source told The Daily Mail that Nickâ€™s family was â€œscaredâ€ of him because of his alleged â€œviolent outbursts,â€ and described Nick as â€œviolent and super aggressive.â€ They claimed that his behavior was often disturbing, but was â€œmagnified to horrific levelsâ€ when he was using substances. Sources alleged that Nick was a â€œticking time bombâ€ and prone to â€œmeth-fueled outburstsâ€ that often included destroying property. An insider alleged that Rob and Michele â€œthreatened to call authorities multiple times, but in the end didnâ€™t.â€

â€œIf they thought he was violent, things would have been very different,â€ a source told PEOPLE. â€œAt the worst of it, it hadnâ€™t been like this. I donâ€™t think anyone could have ever seen anything like this coming. Nick was declining lately but he had been really bad before.â€

Related: Who Is Nick Reinerâ€™s Defense Attorney Alan Jackson?

Is Being Charlie about Rob Reinerâ€™s son?

When Nick got sober (at least at the time), he and Rob collaborated on the 2015 film Being Charlie. The movie was a semi-autobiographical look at a successful filmmaker eyeing a run for political office (played by Cary Elwes, who also starred in Reinerâ€™s classic The Princess Bride) and his strained relationship with his son Charlie (Nick Robinson), who suffers from addiction.

Rob and Nick said that one particular line in the movie, when the father character tells his son, â€œIâ€™d rather you hate me and be alive,â€ came directly from their real-life conversations.

â€œI mean, we did get into fights over things, but ultimately it forced us to make the film better,â€ Rob Reiner said in 2016. â€œThe whole process for meâ€”I can just speak for myselfâ€”it did make me understand him a lot more, and it did make me a better father. Hopefully it did.â€

Related: Watch Rob Reiner and Nick Reiner Talk About Being Charlie a Decade Before the Directorâ€™s Murder

How old is Nick Reiner?

Born Sept. 14, 1993, Nick Reiner is 32 years old as of this writing.

Has Nick Reiner been arrested?

Nick Reiner was arrested without incident at about 9:15 p.m. PT on Sunday, Dec. 14, 2025, hours after his parents were found dead.

Related: LAPD Releases Photos of Nick Reinerâ€™s Arrest

Where was Nick Reiner found?

Police arrested Nick Reiner close to Exposition Park and near the University of Southern California campus, PEOPLE reported. Footage obtained by ABC7 Eyewitness News showed that Nick bought a drink at a gas station moments before police apprehended him. He was wearing a black, green and white striped track jacket, a black cap and blue jeans and was carrying a red backpack at the time.

TMZ reported that Nick had checked into the Pierside Santa Monica hotel, 20 miles from where he was arrested, at about 4 a.m. on Dec. 14, 2025, using his credit card. Spies alleged that Nick was â€œtweaked outâ€ when he checked in, but that he didnâ€™t have any blood visible on his person. His room after he left, however, was a horrifyingly different story: Police who went to the room to investigate reportedly found blood in the shower and on the bed and bedsheets covering the windows.

Sources told TMZ that police told front desk staff at the hotel they were there to do a welfare check on Nick, and ultimately performed a search for the murder weapon on the premises.

TMZ later obtained footage of Nick walking towards the hotel minutes before he checked in (and hours before Rob and Michele Singer Reinerâ€™s bodies were found in their home). In this footage, Nick carries a black backpack, not a red one like he did when he was arrested, so it appears he switched bags at some point after getting to his hotel room and before police apprehended him.

Related: Rob Reinerâ€™s When Harry Met Sally Confession Goes Viral After His and Wife Micheleâ€™s Death

What is Nick Reiner charged with?

On Tuesday, Dec. 16, 2025, Nick Reiner was formally charged with two counts of first-degree murder for the deaths of Michele and Rob Reiner. Assistant district attorney Nathan J. Hochman said in a statement that the charges carry a maximum sentence of life without parole or the death penalty.

Because there were multiple murders, Nick was hit with additional special circumstances, which can add extra time to a prison sentence.

â€œProsecuting these cases involving family members are some of the most challenging and most heart wrenching cases that this office faces because of the intimate and often brutal nature of the crimes involved,â€ Hochman said.

Related: Rob Reinerâ€™s Daughter Tracy Reiner Speaks Out After His Death: â€˜Iâ€™m in Shockâ€™

What is Nick Reinerâ€™s bail?

Nickâ€™s bail was set at $4 million, but he is now being held without bail at the Twin Towers Correctional Facility.

Related: Michelle Obama Reveals She and Barack Had Plans With Rob and Michele Reiner the Day They Died

When is Nick Reinerâ€™s court appearance?

Nick appeared in court briefly on Wednesday, Dec. 17, 2025, TMZ reported. He was seated behind glass and did not enter a plea. His attorney, Alan Jackson, said that the court agreed to formally arraign Nick on Jan. 7, 2025. According to PEOPLE, when asked if he waived his right to a speedy arraignment, Nick replied, â€œYes, your honor.â€ He reportedly wore a suicide prevention vest to court.

PEOPLE previously reported that Jackson told press that Nick Reiner hadnâ€™t been medically cleared to appear in court and that it was a â€œprocedural issue.â€

On Tuesday, Dec. 16, 2025, Hochman said that once Nick had a medical screening, he would be formally arraigned in court.

news.text:

In this episode of Galaxy Brain, Charlie Warzel explores the burgeoning industry of prediction markets. These platforms let people wager on everything from elections and award shows to the most trivial internet ephemera, framing bets as tradable â€œsharesâ€ that rise and fall like stocks. With billions in weekly trading volume, massive new funding rounds, and even a CNN partnership with the prediction-betting platform, Kalshi, prediction markets are quickly moving from niche curiosity to mainstream-media fixtureâ€”openly touting ambitions to financialize everything.

Warzel is joined by writer Max Read, who argues that prediction markets sit at the intersection of gambling, finance, and a broader â€œsuckerificationâ€ economy aimed at young men. Together they unpack whether the markets actually reflect the â€œwisdom of crowdsâ€ or whether theyâ€™re little more than a meta-game of vibes, ideology, and misvalued dumb money. The pair explore the culture of these platforms and offer a diagnosis of the attention economy: When itâ€™s hard to sell anything directly, itâ€™s easier to sell derivatives of everything. Prediction markets may promise clarity, Warzel and Read suggest, but what they really offer is another way to feel excitement in a world that feels rigged.

The following is a transcript of the episode:

Max Read: When I say a â€œsuckerification crisis,â€ I donâ€™t simply mean, Oh, you know, theyâ€™re getting bilked out of their money, though I think thatâ€™s part of it. I think thereâ€™s a whole kind of both commercial and political kind of apparatus that is working really hard to separate young guys from their money.

Charlie Warzel: I am Charlie Warzel, and this is Galaxy Brain. A few weeks ago on this podcast, the journalist Pablo Torre told me this.

Pablo Torre: It feels like, you know, weâ€™re living at a time in which lots of young people were promised things they were not delivered. Perhaps because of the generations that continued to wield power in our government, economy, et cetera, the Boomersâ€”and the way to, like, Chutes and Ladders your way to the American dream is gambling on shit. And in that casino premise, I think you just see again a through line across all these sectors of American life now. Sports being one that has so naturally taken to it. Because, my gosh, hereâ€™s an unlimited menu. I mean, literally.

Warzel: Today weâ€™re going to explore another part of that unlimited menu of gambling in the casino-ification of the American economy: prediction markets. Chances are youâ€™ve been hearing a lot about prediction markets lately. At their core, prediction markets are online spaces where people can place wagers on the outcome of events.

They share similarities with sports books except, unlike a traditional bed at a casino, your wager is a futures contractâ€”the value of which fluctuates based on the market value of the outcome of any given event. Right now, people use the markets to bet on sports, events like the Oscars, whether Elon Musk will tweet a specific number of times in a given month, or about the outcome of an election.

The top platforms now for prediction markets collectively report several billion dollarsâ€™ worth of weekly trading volume. Kalshi, one of the biggest prediction markets in this space, announced this month that it raised a billion dollars from many of Silicon Valleyâ€™s biggest venture-capital firms.

Recently, CNN announced it was partnering with Kalshi to integrate the companyâ€™s prediction-market data in the news coverage. The companyâ€™s CEO, Tarek Mansour, has big ambitions. At a conference in October, he said this about Kalshiâ€™s future:

Tarek Mansour: The long-term vision is to financialize everything and create a tradable asset out of any difference in opinion.

Warzel: â€œFinancialize everything.â€

Thatâ€™s essentially the quiet part out loud. That is the blueprint for the actual casinoification of the world, brought to you by one of the more ascendant companies thatâ€™s moving everything toward gambling. So whatâ€™s really going on here? How do prediction markets work? Is there some truth to what boosters allege: that people putting their money where their mouths are is actually a good way to tap into the wisdom of crowds?

Or is this just a dystopian development? An example of companies preying on a society with a burgeoning gambling addiction? Today I am joined by Max Read, author of the Great Substack Read Max. Read covers culture and power on the internet and has this really intuitive understanding of platforms and people.

Recently he wrote a great piece titled â€œPrediction Markets and the Suckerification Crisis.â€ Max and I talk about where all this is going and why everyone is gambling and no one is happy. Now, my conversation with Max Read.

Warzel: Max Read, welcome to Galaxy Brain.

Read: Thanks for having me, Charlie.

Warzel: Yeah. So weâ€™re going to talk about prediction markets. Hopefully come up with some grand theory as to why they are ascendant and why everything feels a little bit broken. But I want to just firstâ€”for the normies out there who arenâ€™t, you know, using them.

How would you describe them? How are they different from straight-up gambling or a sports book?

Read: Yeah, well, the first time I wrote about them, I described them as sports books that allowed you to place wagers on non-sports events. But I think the extra sort of bit thatâ€™s important to understand about themâ€”because at the end of the day, that is what they are, and itâ€™s the way a lot of people use them. And I should note, by the way, that when I say theyâ€™re not: Theyâ€™re sports books that allow you to place bets on non-sporting events. Many of them are actually also sports books. Kalshi in particular allows you to place wagers on games.

But what they do is really emphasize the wager as a security that you can purchase and sell the way you would a share on the stock market, say. So if you believed, say, that there would be a Democratic sweep across New Jersey, Virginia, and New York City back in November, you could have bought shares. Or you could have bet on that outcome for, you know, what, like 30â€”like, theyâ€™ll do it as prices, right? You bet, you wager 30 cents for the return of a dollar, right? So you could buy the shares at 30 cents. You buy 10 shares at 30 cents; you get $10 back. If that comes off.

Now, I mentioned 30 cents, say, because a couple weeksâ€”Iâ€™m not sure if thatâ€™s the exact priceâ€”but a couple weeks before this election, it was kind of unclear what Democratsâ€™ chances were going to be in any of these elections. Thereâ€™s a lot of polls coming out saying that Mikie Sherrill in New Jersey was running dangerously sort of close in the race against â€¦ I canâ€™t even remember the name of her opponent at this point.

But, you know, it was a fairly low probability according to the betters on the app. Right? But as the returns start to come in on Tuesday nightâ€”and it becomes clear that actually the chances that this is going to be a sweep across all these elections get higherâ€”all of a sudden the price of a given wager rises. Or the price of a given share, so to speak.

So at 30 centsâ€”suddenly itâ€™s 40 cents, suddenly itâ€™s 60 cents. The way you would think about that if you were just talking gambling odds is, all of a sudden, youâ€™re getting less return on your wager, basically. Your odds are getting significantly easier.

And, you could have, sayâ€”let me give a slightly different example of election. So recently in Tennessee, this woman, Aftyn Behn, was running for a congressional seat. And, she was absolutely not the favorite. It was a â€œTrump plus 30â€ congressional district or whatever, and you could buy shares for her victory at like, you know, 20 cents, something like that, the week before the election. The night of the election, as returns start coming in, sheâ€™s looking actually kind of good for it. The early returns are quite good for her. And I watched as the price of her shares climbed up. Iâ€™m not going to say whether or not I had any horse in this race, any money on this. But I was watching it closely, letâ€™s just say.

And there was a point where if you had bought shares at 30â€”and again, who knows who Iâ€™m talking about hereâ€”but if you had bought shares at 30, you could have sold them for a 100 percent profit. Sold them at 60 cents. Only for those shares to come crashing down as the results continue coming over the night, and it becomes clear itâ€™s not happening.

Soâ€”sorry, this is a sort of complicated explanationâ€”but I think itâ€™s useful to understand how you use it. Right? That when you go on these sites, what youâ€™re doing is: Youâ€™re doing this kind of thing thatâ€™s kind of a hybrid. Like stock-market day-trading activity and a betting activity. And I do think itâ€™s worth saying, as much as they emphasize the sort of security, quality of these wagers.

You can do this at a sports book too, right? That odds will change at a sports book depending on whoâ€™s taking which side of the bet, and you can cash out. Most sports books will allow you to cash out various times, you know, after youâ€™ve placed your wager. And if the odds of the wager have changed in between the period where you placed your wager and youâ€™re cashing out, you could make a small profit just from cashing out, right?

If you wager a team is going to win, and then you could cash out with five minutes to go and theyâ€™re up by 20 points, youâ€™re not going to get as much as you would if you saw the whole thing out. But you can cash out at a fairly high profit. So in that sense, you know, itâ€™s sort of another way of looking at, or another way of thinking about, gambling that emphasizes the sort of up-and-down nature of odds. And I think thatâ€™s how most people kind of approach it when theyâ€™re on the site placing these wagersâ€”theyâ€™re thinking about it like betting. But I think itâ€™s also important to understand why [these sites] have become so ubiquitous in media is that they are exciting to a lot of economists and libertarians. especially libertarian economists. Itâ€™s that they offer a kind of semi-accurateâ€”accurate depending on the liquidity of the market, accurate depending on the size of the marketâ€”accurate picture of what you might think of as the conventional wisdom. Right? Because thereâ€™s all these people collectively saying how much [theyâ€™re] placing their own odds, so to speak, on a given outcome.

Wagering their own actual money, so they have skin in the game. So nobodyâ€™s doing this just for propaganda purposes, or whatever. You can say, Conventional wisdom has the chances of this event happening at 50 percent, 30 percent, whatever. Now, these markets are still fairly small, and many of them are not very liquid at all.

So it is not like thereâ€™s millions of people betting a couple bucks at a time to make them, you know, as sort of accurate as possible. Youâ€™ll have a couple whales who are placing large wagers, which makes them interesting in what they tell you. Because itâ€™s not saying, necessarily, the conventional wisdom according to the kind of person who places a bet on this kind of a thing.

But thatâ€™s the other side of it. The nonuser side, the media side, the philosophical side of this is: Prediction markets allow us to start to look at the future in this way that allows us to set probabilities about things.

Warzel: Iâ€™m curious what you make of the â€œwisdom of crowdsâ€ bit, because this is the part of me that stops and feels a little insane sometimes with this. Because I think about, like, this is essentially a meta-game, right? Where you have this system that produces outcomes and incentives for certain outcomes that arise in it, and you wrap that system in an apparatus that is also concerned with influencing those outcomes.

Itâ€™s this second-order thing like you have with pokerâ€”where good poker players can technically predict the outcome of hands, but that is also influencing the outcomes of the games. It just feels to me like what youâ€™re doing is: Prediction markets arenâ€™t what people think will happen. Itâ€™s what people think other people think will happen, right? So it feels to me itâ€™s confusing.

Read: I do think thereâ€™s a use for that. You could come up with reasons. And from a financial sort of market perspective, one way of thinking about it is that these are effectively tools. Instruments for hedging, right?

That you have a sense ofâ€”you think somethingâ€™s going to happen, but you also want to place some wagers on the side in case it doesnâ€™t happen to limit your losses. And for that, you donâ€™t need it to be wholly accurate, right? You just need it to sort of approximate a given outcome that allows you to make money off of that.

I think thereâ€™s sort of two ways to go with what youâ€™re saying. One is that, until recently, prediction markets have largely been a sort of theoretical idea, right? I mean, we could talk about the stock marketâ€”or a sports book, for that matterâ€”as a prediction market. But this sort of all-encompassing marketplace to make wagers on.

I mean, recently there were wagers on the Time magazine â€œPerson of the Yearâ€ cover, all the Oscars, all the award-season stuff. You can wager on whoâ€™s going to get nominated and whoâ€™s going to win. Weâ€™ve talked about elections already. Thereâ€™s even, often, marketplaces for words getting mentioned by prominent figures inâ€”whatâ€™s the word Iâ€™m looking forâ€”in speeches or in, you know, earnings calls. If you believe really strongly in the idea of the wisdom of crowds, itâ€™s very exciting.

But the theoretical model of the prediction market is, as I was sort of emphasizing before, is one that everybody is participating in. The market is fully liquid. Everybody has a stake in it. Everybody is placing wagers there. And these markets are fairly far from that, right? On Election Night, there tends to be enough money, and enough people, to sort of approximate what weâ€™ve been talking about as the conventional wisdom about whoâ€™s going to win and whoâ€™s going to lose.

But thatâ€™s not always the case, and certainly not the case for stuff like these culture categories that Iâ€™m talking about. I wanted to askâ€”without you having to divulge whether you are, or are not, actively participating in these marketsâ€”whatâ€™s the culture like on these? I think it mirrors some of the culture on X/Twitter in the Musk era.

But when you go either to try to place some wagers, or for reporting purposes,whatâ€™s the culture like?

Read: So, I can talk about the culture in the comment sectionsâ€”which I wouldnâ€™t want to suggest is wholly reflective of the culture of these places in general.

And I think there is a wide range. There is smart money. There are sharks out there who are running programs and bots to identify. Especially on an election night, youâ€™ll get guys who are pulling results all doing this automated, basically HFDâ€”like high-frequency traders pulling results from The New York Times or Decision Desk or whoever. And, like, immediately placing orders on shares to take advantage of that. Like, you donâ€™t have to do it in the milliseconds the way you do on Wall Street, but you can do it if you just do it in a couple seconds. Weâ€™ll still make it advantageous.

And you have people who are quite goodâ€”for example, the Time magazine cover leaked before it was announced. And a bunch of people made a tidy little profit, because it took a while for the market to catch up. So I say that just to say that there are smart people. Just as a to be sure thing before I get into the commentsâ€”which are really stupid. I mean, thereâ€™s just a lot of stupid people there. And thereâ€™s a funny mix of just really obviously stupid peopleâ€”you know, Free Republicâ€“commenter type, X, like bottom-of-the-barrel, Trumpist X types. And then thereâ€™s stupid, just guys who have sort of wandered in. Every wager, if you scroll far enough, youâ€™ll find a guy who took the stupid side of the wager because he didnâ€™t read the terms until after heâ€™d put his $50 down.

He is like, Oh, I didnâ€™t realize that I was actually betting, you know, against this. I thought I was betting for it. Oh, well, now Iâ€™m out 50 bucks. The tone reminds me a lot ofâ€”I think the closest thing I can think of online, or the two closest things, are the: If you play fantasy football in Yahoo, every player has their own little comment section. And you can pull it up as youâ€™re deciding whoâ€™s to start and who to bench.

And itâ€™s just filled with people just clinging to the most desperate of threads. You know, citing articles they read somewhere. Nobodyâ€™s linking to anything. Everyoneâ€™s like, Oh, I heard he is going to play. Oh, I heard he is injured. Oh, I heard heâ€™s, you know, heâ€™s not going to be the first QB.

Heâ€™s not going to get any catches. He is not going to get any throws this game. Whatever it is. And the comments on the bets kind of remind me of this on all the markets. Itâ€™s somebody being like, Oh, you know, thereâ€™s one market thatâ€™s which member of Trumpâ€™s Cabinet is going to leave first.

And everyoneâ€™s like, Well, okay, well hereâ€™s this thing I read about [Pete] Hegseth. And somebody else will be like, Well, I read this about Pam Bondi. And people doing their theories. Itâ€™s a message board. Itâ€™s not the dumbest place Iâ€™ve ever read, but itâ€™s of a basic kind of politics message-board stupidity.

Itâ€™s just that thereâ€™s all this money going on in the background. All of which is to say, when I say itâ€™s similar to the fantasy-football chats is: Itâ€™s very male. Obviously itâ€™s very young. Obviously, I meanâ€”I think most of the guys are sort of in their 20s. Itâ€™s sort of confident, but Ill-informed in the way you would expect a lot of guys who to gamble in their 20s basically are.

Warzel: Thereâ€™s alsoâ€”and I donâ€™t mean this in a pearl-clutching wayâ€”but itâ€™s a little reactionary. Right? Because part of what I see in the elevator pitch from some of the founders of thisâ€”itâ€™s trying to court people who have some skepticism about the way that institutions behave, right? Kalshiâ€™s co-founder, Tarek Mansour, I think is how you say his name. Heâ€™s really positioned this as the â€œwisdom of crowds,â€ because regular institutions have failed us, right? Because thereâ€™s this plethora of information out there, because reporters arenâ€™t actually very good at telling, or getting, the story the way it isâ€”come here. Not only is this a helpful tool, but that seems to recruit, just generally, people who a little bit more edgelord-y, or whatever. Yeah. Is that accurate to you?

Read: I think so. I mean, I thinkâ€”certainly, not to sort of underline this pointâ€”but I do think itâ€™s worth thinking about the prediction markets in two phases.

Thereâ€™s, especially, the ones around politics. Thereâ€™s the long phase before the election, whatever election is being bet on, happens. Which, I think, there is aâ€”I donâ€™t want to put a number on it, but I think that the markets tend to lean right? They just tend to overestimate Republicans. They tend toâ€”not by a significant amount, not by the amount that you can make a ton of money off of unless youâ€™re gambling a lotâ€”but generally they tend to give Republicans better odds and Democrats worse odds. Thatâ€™s phase one. And then, phase two is closer to the actual election. And thatâ€™s, in my experience, at least, when the smart money starts to roll in. And people come through just to pick upâ€”basically, they take the transition from â€œthe marketâ€™s tilting Republicanâ€ to reality setting in, and they make a quick profit off of that.

And then, by the end of the night, we know who won, and the markets are settled. Theyâ€™re mostly settled. So I think that: Yes, the culture, in that sense, tilts right. I think that thereâ€™s also sort of two aspects to why that is. The first is exactly as youâ€™re saying: that there is a deep and longstanding philosophical affinity between predictions markets, the wisdom of crowds, so to speak.

The idea that markets, in general, can calculate things better than institutions or humans can. That dates back to [Friedrich] Hayek and [Ludwig von] Mises. And this is sort of foundational to, you might say, neoliberalism in some broad sense. But also to a lot of the way that Silicon Valley has thought about the world since the â€™90s.

Right. You know, thereâ€™s this idea that we donâ€™t want top-down people in charge. We want this sort of collective, anarchic mass of humanity working together. And a market or a quasi-market format will pull these together. So I think there is this kind of highfalutin, letâ€™s say, philosophical background here that probably pushes the prediction marketsâ€”the people who use them and certainly the people who build themâ€”to the right. To the kind of libertarian, hard-libertarian, market-worshiping right. But there also is a particular sort of base, reactionary nest to a lot of what goes on there, that I think is more tied in withâ€”to some extent takes its cues fromâ€”the sort of intellectual draws that Iâ€™ve just been talking about. But is more tied into one being young and male. And gamblingâ€”young men like to gamble; young men tend to be more right wing.

So I think thatâ€™s just sort of a basic demographic and sociological fact of 2025. Theyâ€™re also pulling in a lot of people from X, which is just significantly more right wing than it was five years ago. And, as I was saying, they also areâ€”without wanting to be too smug about itâ€”theyâ€™re trying to pull in, through their marketing campaigns, pull in a lot of dumb money. To make it attractive for smart money to come in.

And they do that by advertising to the biases of the reactionaries on X, basically. So, I decided to write about this because, around the time of the November elections when Zohran Mamdani was running high in New York City, but as is often the case, thereâ€™s a lot of people in New York who hated him. Who were sort of, Well, I donâ€™t think heâ€™s going to win.

You know, I think people there [were], as you were saying, The mainstream media is ignoring all my neighbors that hate him. All my neighbors are going to vote against him. And Kalshi started running. And Polymarket, too, started running all of these. They own these, um. They run these sort of newswire accounts, that are depending on both the official accounts. But also they have their own news accounts that they donâ€™t link to the betting sites, really. They just do these blanket, one-line, almost like a Bloomberg-terminal news thing that tends to be very misleading. Very right wing.

You know, in one case Kalshi tweetedâ€”sometimes theyâ€™ll tweet about the prediction markets. And theyâ€™ll be like, Zohran Mamdaniâ€™s position is tumbling. And that kind of thing is obviously going to bring in â€¦ you know, you could do that with liberals. I donâ€™t wanna pretend that liberals in America are so much better at picking out misinformation and scams and whatever else. But itâ€™s very clear who they want to appeal to on Twitter. And itâ€™s low-social-trust gamblers, basically.

Warzel: Yeah. And also, just even beyond the political part of it. Some of these accounts that are run by these prediction marketsâ€”like Kalshi, Polymarketâ€”are just trolling, right? Thereâ€™s this one image of 49ers running back Christian McCaffrey with the caption â€œLoves receiving balls,â€ right?

And it was just this big sort of trade, or â€œon the disabled listâ€â€“style, graphic. But again, as you said, they donâ€™t link to it. But itâ€™s almost just kind of like, Weâ€™re having fun on here, too. Why donâ€™t you come have fun on our place, and, you know, take advantage of this?

But, you talk about this dumb money. And you described it, in this great Substack post that weâ€™ll link to, as the part of the male â€œsuckerification crisis.â€ And can you elaborate a little more on that? I think thatâ€™s sort of your corollary to the male loneliness crisis theyâ€™re in. But what are you saying here?

Read: I feel like one of the big stories on the internetâ€”and in society at largeâ€”over the last five years or so has been the extent to which young men have fallen under the spell, or the sway, of a variety of different kinds of scammers, hucksters, fraudsters. When I say a â€œsuckerification crisis,â€ I donâ€™t simply mean, Oh, you know, theyâ€™re getting bilked out of their money. Though I think thatâ€™s part of it. I think thereâ€™s a whole kind ofâ€”both commercial and politicalâ€”apparatus that is working really hard to separate young guys from their money.

And I think that thereâ€™s something about, I donâ€™t have a grand â€¦ you know, this is more of a corkboard-and-red-yarn theory than an equation, right? Warzel: We love that. Read: But I see these connections. I see these sort of basic dynamics play out in straight old-fashioned sports gambling, which has sort of taken over sports media. That was legalized a few years ago and now kind of dominates the way we talk about sports in the country. At least, in the media that has written about sports and filmed about sports. I see it in prediction markets as well. Talking about this, sort of, Kalshi and Polymarket Twitter feeds that weâ€™re talking about. You know, the sense that This is gambling kind of creeping into even more layers of life, layers of social life.

I see it in the kind of manosphere-influencer guys. These sort of perennial subjects, objects of moral panic. But, you knowâ€”the main sort of dynamic I see there is not necessarily even kind of ideological, radicalization on the part of somebody like Andrew Tate. But the way that they are selling a particular story and a particular product to a bunch of young men that kind of cultivates them as suckers, that turns them into suckers.

And I think that Trumpist politicsâ€”by which I mean both the Republican Party under Donald Trump, but also all kinds of right-wing, reactionary politicsâ€”emerge out of the same sort of soup. You know. This highly emotive insistence thatâ€”as you sort of put it earlierâ€”Institutions are failing you, but weâ€™ve got the cure. Weâ€™ve got the ticket; you can participate in this movement. You can show everybody that youâ€™re smarter than everybody else. Hereâ€™s the secret to making money. Hereâ€™s the secret to, you know, winning in politics. Hereâ€™s the secret to getting girls. Whatever it is. Itâ€™s funny to me how much you can sort of see that same dynamic across what should, theoretically, be these quite different kinds of spheres. But seem to, in fact, kind of be converging on this one sort of business model, more or less.

You know, just to provide some historical perspectiveâ€”Rick Perlstein, the historian, has a really wonderful essay in The Baffler from maybe 10 or more years ago that I think about all the time in terms of this.
