That you go on Twitterâ€”itâ€™s a social media site. Itâ€™s, you know, highly volatile. Youâ€™re constantly feeling like everybody else is getting more views than you.

Youâ€™re constantly sort of feeling youâ€™re in this strange space that you donâ€™t necessarily understand. You know, youâ€™re surrounded by people who are expressing that same strange feeling. It feels a lot like being in the economy, too, doesnâ€™t it? And isnâ€™t politics also this strange, volatile space?

Surely thereâ€™s a way we can all make a little extra money off of it. Weâ€™re constantly in competition. Itâ€™s not a hard-and-fast theory. Itâ€™s this set of affective triggers, right? These sort ofâ€”this vibe thatâ€™s out there that seems to be quite inescapable. In particular for, you know, recent college graduates. Kids in college, even in high school,

Warzel: Right. And thereâ€™s this way that itâ€™s this reinforcing system, right? If you do fall into those, into that mindset, you enter into a place that sort of embraces the chaos, embraces the precarity therein, right? And then feeling all that gives you. The only possible way out, right?

The only possible latch onto a kind of, you know, new version of the American Dream. Which is just like, I buy this memecoin low, I sell high. Right? I get in this place here, and itâ€™sâ€”but that usually doesnâ€™t work out well for most people, right? A lot of the dumb money. And then you get back in this cycle of precarity resentment.

Okay, now we have the antidote to that. And the cycle just repeats over and over again.

Read: One thing I would add, that I didnâ€™t really write about in this pieceâ€”but that has been something on my mind for a long time, because I feel it tooâ€”is a sort of increasing sense in American society that everybody else is getting one over on you and/or the system.

And that in fact, if you let everybody else get one over on you, you are weak, and you have made a mistake. You know, you are a sucker. When, in fact, I think in many ways itâ€™s sort of the reverse. That itâ€™s like, if youâ€™re constantly tryingâ€”if youâ€™re the one whoâ€™s constantly trying to get one overâ€”you probably are a sucker yourself.

And, you know, I think thereâ€™sâ€”I mean, the root cause here, I would say, is sort of society-wide breakdown of trust in institutions. You know, in the sense that institutions are in it for themselves, and they are, you know, corrupt. And giving handouts to their people and not to you.

Again, this is also this sort of vibe that seeps out and powers a lot of the kind of activity around predictions markets. But also around a bunch of these other businesses and figures.

Warzel: I wanna test out a theory on all this thatâ€™s maybe another side of it. Or maybe itâ€™s just this in a different skin, but which is, very broadly, this idea that itâ€™s exceedingly hard in a mature attention economy to sell something, right?

And it is because of all the competition for attention. And itâ€™s much easier to sell a derivative of that thing. I read this post a couple weeks ago that was talking about movie marketing, and how itâ€™s kind of just gone haywire. And this idea that stars are doing things that arenâ€™t like a traditional junket, where theyâ€™re talking about the film with a hundred different people. But theyâ€™re going on a hundred different podcasts or, you know, video shows or whatever.

And basically doing viral skits, right? You can kind of start at Hot Ones. But then you can trace this to Jennifer Lawrence and her co-star Robert Pattinson doing lie-detector tests, right? A lot of celebrities doing lie-detector tests for Vanity Fair or whatever. And itâ€™s good content. People watch it. People are interested in it. Itâ€™s good for the timeline. But it historically is not selling these movies, right? Because theyâ€™re not talking about the film. Theyâ€™re talking about themselves in the hope that theyâ€™re going to garner enough attention to sell a film.

Right? And, I think of that idea of a derivative of something. I think about it, very obviously, with sports gambling, right? Leagues are interested in having this, because it does draw attention to the games, right? Adam Silver, the NBAâ€™s commissioner, wrote this op-ed 10 years ago or so, kind of advocating to legalize sports gambling.

And thereâ€™s this idea that it will draw in interest and attention to this event. But itâ€™s interest and attention essentially to, you know, a game within a game. Right? People are interested in hitting the over; theyâ€™re interested in, you know, how many free throws so-and-so gets. Or, you know, misses. Or whatever, right?

And Iâ€™m curious if you feel this too? Thatâ€”we see it with elections, right? It doesnâ€™t matter so much about the outcome as much as it is getting the edge. And this idea of financialization of everything. Just creating derivatives of everything to the point where itâ€™s almost impossible to sell a thing.

Read: Yeah. I mean, I think that this is part of the attraction of the prediction market over the regular sports book, too. I guess itâ€™s not just derivatives; itâ€™s securitization. And that you create this object that you can sell and resell at whatever.

You know, I donâ€™t want to drive the metaphor off a cliff or whatever. But one of the interesting things about those viral videos of, say, Pattinson and Jennifer Lawrence doing the lie-detector test, as you sayâ€”probably not very useful for marketing the movie. But that video is now useful to Vanity Fair, or whoever it was that filmed it. And will be useful to them for 10 years, because those are going to be famous people that people will wanna see for 10 years.

Lord knows, thereâ€™s no time limit for anything on the internet. You now have this thing that just kind of exists in the world. And I think that thereâ€™s a real difficulty to find ways to have those derivatives, to maintain their relationship to the bigger project thatâ€™s supposed to be pushing forward. The other thing, I would say, that sports thingâ€”what you were saying about sports makes me think is that part of this is about media in general. Right? That weâ€™re increasingly difficult to figure out how to pay for the media that exists, and that we think of presumably as sort of integral to democracy. To our liberal democratic system. And sports arguably runs a little bit ahead of political media, news media, in terms of business models and whatever else. And one of the big reasons that Adam Silver has been an advocate for legalizing gamblingâ€”and one of the reasons why all of the media companies, ESPN chief among them, have so enthusiastically embraced sports bettingâ€”is that we sort of have reached peak sports.

Weâ€™re a little bit over the hill in peak sports. Basketball is a very good example, becauseâ€”you know, Mark Cuban was talking about this just last yearâ€”nobody thinks the next few TV deals are going to be anywhere near as lucrative as the last few TV deals are. Where the question is: Who is making money and how are they making money?

And thatâ€™s not just the question for the team owners, who will always make money from the stadium, right? And from the actual games themselves. But how is ESPN going to make money? And the answer, right now, seems to be gambling. Weâ€™re going to take gambling sponsorships; weâ€™re going to talk about gambling all the time.

So when we talk about, like Kalshi and Polymarket. You know, why is CNN so enthusiastic about bringing them on? I mean, they already are, in fact, partnering with Kalshi to, I thinkâ€”or maybe with Polymarketâ€”to produce odds for them on Election Night. And presumably elsewhere during the political season.

And so I think thereâ€™s the other part of it, in addition to the kind of structural. The way we think about marketing and attention is to break things off into these little pieces that can be bought and sold. In the last 10 years, itâ€™s that we are facing a crisis for how we pay for these things. And gambling is a traditionally fairly lucrative industry to be in. And, you know, thatâ€™s a way that CNN could take itself.

Warzel: You donâ€™t want Cousin Sal to moderate Meet the Press going forward. I feel like thatâ€™s a great idea. The partnership is between Kalshi and CNN, and I think that, youâ€™re absolutely right about the â€œpaying for itâ€ part of it. Which is obviously the most important part.

I also think that there is this attentional quality that injects a little bit ofâ€”Iâ€™m trying to think about this. You know, it feels so dystopian having CNNâ€™s Harry Enten, the polling guy, is going to be the one whoâ€™s going to be doing the big board and looking through the Kalshi odds, what theyâ€™ve said.

And it feels a little dystopian to have that partnership. But also, it injects, I thinkâ€”for them trying to rationalize it in some wayâ€”some excitement into something. That, when you said weâ€™ve reached peak sports a while back, weâ€™ve reached peak politics too.

We are well beyond peak politics, where everyone is just sort of ground down by, you know, how this works. But also kind of strangely, terminally addicted to it at the same time. You canâ€™t quit it, but thereâ€™s nothing in it. And this is sort ofâ€”whatever derivative, a securitization. Itâ€™s some element that I think also injects â€¦ people joke about horse-race coverage. And itâ€™s like, no: Weâ€™re actually making a horse race now.

Read: The problem with horse-race coverage was that we didnâ€™t have the horse race yet.

Warzel: Our mutual friend and fellow tech writer John Herrman wrote a thing for the Neiman Labâ€™s year-end predictions here for 2026â€”that the media will become addicted to gambling, follow the path of sports media.

Itâ€™s very smart. Do you feel like this is just going to get worse? Where do you see this all moving? Is it just increasingly lawless, like weâ€™re just going to, you know, fall victim to all this? Do you think this is a kind of a fad? Do you think this is maybe something that actually is the injection of capital that these places need? How do you sort of project it going forward?

Read: I am not necessarily as pessimistic. I think that the forces are arrayed in favor of the prediction market becoming a sort of dominant means by which we interpret and understand the world around us.

Thereâ€™s a lot of money behind thatâ€”and thereâ€™s a lot of powerful philosophical and political ideas that want to see something like this, you know, take a larger role in society. And the truth is, in addition to â€¦ I donâ€™t even mean to make it sound that sinister. Like, from a bankerâ€™s point of view, a stock traderâ€™s point of view, having all these extra hedging instruments is useful. From the point of view of CNN on Election Night, setting aside this sort of question of how much gambling is going to dominate CNN, the prediction markets give us something to talk about that is not that different in terms of its relationship to realityâ€”from polls, say.

So all this stuff is the money, the philosophy, the use. All that stuff is lined up in a way that gives prediction markets, I think, a big sort of runway to find themselves. To become more and more prominent. And to intermediate more areas of life. That being said, weâ€™ve seen, since 2022â€”when, I think, sports gambling was legalized in New Yorkâ€”weâ€™ve seen how much sports gambling has taken over sports media. How much sports betting has sort of become this ubiquitous thing in coverage. But my impressionâ€”and I think this bears out in most of the polling thatâ€™s been done recentlyâ€”so people actually hate this. Even the young men who are supposed to be the customers donâ€™t really like it very much.

And I think that same quality is going to be true of prediction markets. I think thereâ€™s a very particularâ€”this is just baseless theorization right here; this is my own version of astrologyâ€”but I think thereâ€™s a certain kind of person whose brain works in this particular, letâ€™s say Bayesian way. Where they are constantly thinking about things in terms of odds. Where they are calculating in their own heads, you know, arbitrage opportunities and what kinds of bets theyâ€™re willing to, you know. Theyâ€™re doing Kelly criterion bets and whatever calculations in their heads.

And I think for those people, these things are incredibly exciting. I think those people are also really heavily concentrated in Silicon Valley and Wall Street, basically. Those are the places you go if thatâ€™s the kind of brain you have. I think a lot of the rest of us find it â€¦ I mean, I could speak for myself alone, but I know Iâ€™m not alone. That kind of way of being in the worldâ€”way of thinking about the worldâ€”is exhausting. Youâ€™re not really thinking about the game. Youâ€™re thinking about the over; youâ€™re thinking about the props that youâ€™ve put together.

Youâ€™re thinking about the parlay across the three different games. I think that prediction markets being inserted everywhere else has a very similar kind of quality to it. I wonder if thereâ€™s a happy medium? I think with sports betting, what many people sort of now these days believe is that there should not be apps for it.

It shouldnâ€™t really be legal. There should be a guy that if you have the social wherewithal to find, you can place a bet with, right? But it shouldnâ€™t be the kind of thing where they just roll out the red carpet, and thereâ€™s a lubricated path to losing all of your money.

And Iâ€™m pretty sympathetic to that. I donâ€™t know if that makes me an old man.

Warzel: I think what youâ€™re saying is: Friction is a good thing, right? Friction is helpful here. And a lot of these betting apps â€¦ I actually canâ€™t speak to Kalshi or Polymarket, but like the the DraftKings, FanDuelâ€”theyâ€™re literally sending push notifications. Of like, This is about to happen. You know, whatever it is.

Itâ€™s not even neutral, in the sense that itâ€™s easily accessible. Itâ€™s like the bookie is sitting on your couch, you know? Asking you if youâ€™d like to get in on this. Right? So you have that element; you have the idea that gambling itself in all thingsâ€”whether itâ€™s on elections, whether itâ€™s on whateverâ€”gambling is not a static thing, right? Every different type. Thereâ€™s so many different types of gambling, of ways to bet, that can give you slightly better odds. Or that are, you know, based off of skill instead of blind luck. And the idea that the closer you get to the slot machine, right? Just pull and, you know, a couple of things have to line upâ€”thatâ€™s the worst part of gambling. And thatâ€™s what we are moving toward; this tech-enabled stuff tends to resemble that more than it resembles, you know, betting on whoâ€™s going to win in a golf match, with your friends or whatever. And then I think youâ€™re right about the exhaustion of it all.

And it reminds me of the nature of these companies, right? This focus and need on scaling. A lot of these companiesâ€”like Kalshi just raised a billion dollars earlier in December from some of the major tech venture capitalists. Theyâ€™re obviously going to need to scale. Their CEO said now, infamously, the goal is to financialize every single difference of opinion in the world. Which, as you put, is patently the most exhausting thing you could imagine.

No disagreement goes unmonetized is likeâ€”just end it all now. I think, unlike you, I do feel itâ€™s a little sinister. Listening to you talk about the relationship of the risk, the volatility, you know, the gambling, the sort of reactionary poking and prodding and trolling on X to get you in the funnel, to put you into this precarious situation.

All of that, to me, actually feels it is bad. And that feels dominant to me, over â€œThis is a really great way to get a birdâ€™s-eye view of a situation.â€

Read: I probably am being too kind. I do think it is sinister. And I think that itâ€™s bad in an absolute sense. But I am, alsoâ€”I feel like itâ€™s good to be conscious of the uses that it has. And the kinds of forces that are arrayed in its favor. And that itâ€™s not a cash grab, and itâ€™s not a kind of, necessarily, a pure philosophical disputeâ€”that there are serious institutions for whom this represents a windfall or a new method of doing what they do.

I wonder a little bit. Let me preface this by saying this, as a sort of depressing thought that Iâ€™m not necessarily endorsing. But, you know, one reason I think that sports gambling has taken off so wildlyâ€”and one reason I think even stuff like fantasy football, which is in some ways quite similar to gambling, but obviously also very different in important waysâ€”is the extent to which sports as a pastime, or as an entertainment, represent a kind of â€¦ Iâ€™ll take baseball for an example.

Say that baseball is kind of a solved game. You have a pretty good sense at the very beginning of the season. You know people are very good at projecting whoâ€™s going to win, how many wins thereâ€™re going to be. What youâ€™re waiting for is injuries. And then, the playoffs.

Itâ€™s not luck, but itâ€™s basically luck. I say that, you knowâ€”itâ€™s probably the greatest World Series of my lifetime, this past year. But one thing that I think that gambling allows us to do in in a worldâ€”in, like, the NBA, when a third of regular-season games, most of the stars just flat out arenâ€™t playing. Which I know that the NBA hates, but is also exactly what you need to do, because thatâ€™s a problem that has now been solved by resting people.

What you find yourself wanting to get: the sense of volatilityâ€”the sense of unexpected delight and whatever else gambling becomesâ€”the way you get out of sports. That what feels harder and harder to get as more and more money gets applied to, like, figuring out the secrets to winning each one of these.

And Iâ€™m not sure what the way to apply that is as a metaphor to the rest of the world out there. But I think that part of what the attraction here, too, is taking things that have been optimized to hell. Like, whatever it is. The things that no longer give you the same kind of burst of enjoyment because you know what to expect from them, at all times.

And the gamblingâ€”you know, the prediction market, the gambling, the wagers. They give you that little extra burst of dopamine, energy, enjoyment, excitement. Because all of a sudden youâ€™re attaching some money to something that isnâ€™t the necessarily even the main point of the game. And I think, to me, thatâ€™s depressing. Because Iâ€™m sympathetic to it. Right. Though Iâ€™m sympathetic to that desire to try and find the same kind of enjoyment. But also because thatâ€™s the thing that, I think, hooks peopleâ€”more than the sort of sense that, Oh, I can find the edge by doing my calculations in my head. And every dispute is going to be financialized, and weâ€™re going to figure that out.

Itâ€™s more like: I just wanna take a little risk somewhere. Like, a fairly safe risk. Just to give myself â€¦ just to feel something, somewhere. Just to feel something.

Warzel: The thing that makes me think about with sportsâ€”especially in baseball, where weâ€™re about to go into, a year from now, these major labor disputes with the unionsâ€”is this inequality, right? There is this fundamental inequality in baseball between the haves and the have-nots. And the big-market teams and the Cincinnati Reds. Or like, you know, what have you. And in that, you do have that situation often in a fanbase of Okay, well, if we make the playoffs, weâ€™re going to get, you know, absolutely destroyed in the first round. And thatâ€™s a good year. And â€œenjoy the ride,â€ right? But itâ€™s getting something else there. And then when I try to thinkâ€”does that apply broadly out to politics?

Of course, maybe not exactly, right? Itâ€™s not a total inequality thing. But it is this sort of feeling like the system isnâ€™t going to move, right? Like itâ€™s sclerotic in this way. Like youâ€™re not going to get a candidate thatâ€™s just going to come out of nowhere, unless you have, you know, these instances like Mamdani.

Read: I mean, look at how much energy, I mean, even Kamala Harrisâ€™s emergenceâ€”in 18 hours as the Democratic nominee, after [Joe] Biden [dropped out], had that burst of energy. Because it was such an unexpected historical event. Even if she was, you know, not the most exciting candidate to young people in the world, or whatever. She was a sort ofâ€”exactly who you wouldâ€™ve â€œexpect the unexpectednessâ€ about. It gave that extra bit of energy.

Warzel: I think that that is such a good way to frame all of this in a world thatâ€™s feeling a little bit locked, right? Where everything seems a little locked, this is injecting a kind of chaos that allows people to feel.

Read: I think thatâ€™s real. Well, the other thingâ€”and I would say two things on top of that. One is: I thinkâ€”just to reconnect some of the stuff we were talking about beforeâ€”I think it is relatively similar to some of the appeal of social networks, which have a volatility to them. And I think that one of the reasons that Twitter is lessâ€”and Facebook too, are less and less, and Instagram evenâ€”become less and less interesting to people is probably because they become sort of solved games. And, you know, what does well in the algorithm. What does well. Itâ€™s much harder to have that pop of the thing that you get really early on a social networkâ€”always like, Iâ€™ve never seen something like this before. This is so weird. This kind of person, you could still sort of find it there. But those that like volatility, itâ€™s there in a certain limited way. But not in the same way. The other thing, I would say, is that this feeling weâ€™re talking aboutâ€”I think whatâ€™s at stake is a sense that thereâ€™s very little to surprise us anymore.

And this is, again, a sort of a vibe more than it is a fact. But there is this vibe of, like, Everythingâ€™s optimized to hell. Everybody, for the most part, acts really cautious in their given settings, the domains in which theyâ€™re playing. Itâ€™s hard to find surprise. Gambling at least gives us some level of, you knowâ€”allows us to feel something, as we put it.

But what prediction markets effectively do, over the long term, is even eliminate that from gambling. Because what youâ€™re doingâ€”once the market is big enough, once enough people are bettingâ€”all of a sudden all the surprises are kind of gone. Except for weather events, right?

Itâ€™s the last thing that you could bet on: where thereâ€™s some possibly there wonâ€™t be rain, despite the 90 percentâ€“chance forecast the next day. And I think itâ€™s self-defeating. I suppose. I donâ€™t like â€¦ thatâ€™s a science-fiction story more than it is something that we really have to worry about at this point.

But I think that ultimately the point of the prediction market is to reassert the primacy of locked-in predictions. Even if what makes it interesting right now is the enjoyment of risk and novelty and surprise.

Warzel: I love the idea that eventually the prediction market, it eats its own young at the end of it. I think thatâ€™s a great place to leave it. Max Read, thank you so much for coming on Galaxy Brain.

Read: It was absolutely my pleasure. Thanks for this great conversation.

Warzel: Thatâ€™s it for us here. Thank you again to my guest, Max Read. If you liked what you saw here, new episodes of Galaxy Brain drop every Friday. news.title: How Bad Is It for Dems? Their Decision on Releasing Their 2024 Autopsy Report Says It All
news.text:
As we reported, new polling brought some bad news for congressional Democrats. 

They hit their lowest rating ever, with only 18 percent approval, 73 percent disapproval in a new Quinnipiac poll.

As CNN data guru Harry Enten explained, they were "-55 net approval, an all-time low & lower than the Dead Sea." 

What was worse for them was that even amongst their own party, they were underwater, with only 42 percent approving and 48 percent disapproving. Their party approval had taken a nosedive since October, after they failed in the government shutdown fight. 

Despite that, they were ahead on the generic ballot by about four points. But as Enten noted, this should be much higher normally for the midterms, where the party out of power usually has the advantage. It showed how weak they were.

Now, on Friday, two new polls, Emerson and Quantus Insights, show Democrats only up by two points in the generic ballot, which is even better than the numbers Enten had mentioned. Quantus has it at 43 to 41 percent, and Emerson has it at 44 to 42 percent. 

Then, on top of that, the DNC's Ken Martin announced that they wouldn't be releasing the autopsy report on why they lost in 2024. 

Ken Martin, the chairman of the D.N.C., said on Thursday that he had decided not to publish a report that he ordered months ago into what went wrong for the Democratic Party last year. Party officials have conducted more than 300 interviews with Democrats in all 50 states to create a document that Mr. Martin had once pitched as crucial to charting a path forward. Mr. Martin will instead keep the findings under seal. He believes that looking back so publicly and painfully at the past would prove counterproductive for the party as it tries next year to take back power in Congress, according to a D.N.C. spokeswoman who spoke on the condition of anonymity to share the thinking behind his decision. â€œHereâ€™s our North Star: Does this help us win?â€ Mr. Martin said in a statement. â€œIf the answer is no, itâ€™s a distraction from the core mission.â€

Translation? The report shows how bad their issues are; it will hurt and embarrass them. So, like typical Democrats, they just wasted all that time and money because they don't like the reality of what they were told. 

They haven't answered the question, for example, of how Kamala Harris' team threw $1.5 billion down the sewer and didn't even manage to win one swing state. 

Simon Bazelon, a Democratic researcher, noted how this decision doesn't help them solve their issues and was "reflective of a broader problem within the party." You can say that again. This is "hide your head in the sand" behavior. 

They appear to want to return to their strategy of 2024, just yelling about President Donald Trump. 

Republicans have a real chance here; they need to focus on the economy. They need to remind everyone what a mess things were under the Democrats, going up to 9 percent on inflation, and what they are doing to make things better, as Trump did during his economic address on Wednesday.

Thursday's inflation number was good, at 2.7 percent. Gas is down, wages are up, and more good things are on the horizon. Keep focusing on making things better and getting that message out there.

news.title: The DNC just torpedoed its long-awaited 2024 autopsy. That’s a mistake.
news.text:
When Ken Martin was elected chair of the Democratic National Committee in February, he promised a report investigating what went wrong for his party in 2024. â€œThe reality is what we need to do right now is really start to get a handle around what happened last election cycle,â€ he told reporters. â€œWe know that we lost ground with Latino voters, we know we lost ground with women and younger voters and of course working-class voters. We donâ€™t know the how and why yet.â€

Ten months later, Martin has made a remarkable reversal. He will not release the long-awaited autopsy, he announced on Thursday, even though itâ€™s done. Despite months of work â€” including hundreds of interviews with party operatives in all 50 states â€” and a pledge to use the report to drive the party forward, Martin appears to have decided that publishing it would be a â€œdistraction.â€ 

That the DNC is mothballing whatever audit it could bring itself to conduct underscores that the party remains petrified of its own reflection.

â€œIn our conversations with stakeholders from across the Democratic ecosystem, we are aligned on whatâ€™s important, and thatâ€™s learning from the past and winning the future. Hereâ€™s our North Star: does this help us win? If the answer is no, itâ€™s a distraction from the core mission,â€ Martin said in a statement explaining his decision.

Strangely, Martin doesnâ€™t seem to perceive the conflict in deeming â€œlearning from the pastâ€ important and then torpedoing his partyâ€™s attempt to do so. 

Shelving the document isnâ€™t exactly a disaster: Leaks to the press as the DNC autopsy was being assembled suggested that the report would be a comically superficial analysis, mostly thanks to the committeeâ€™s narrow scope of investigation. But combine the less-than-rigorous postmortem and the about-face on releasing it, and Democrats should be embarrassed. 

To understand how allergic the party remains to any serious introspection, consider that in July, The New York Times, citing people briefed on the process of the DNC audit, reported that it was â€œexpected to avoid the questions of whether former President Joseph R. Biden Jr. should have run for re-election in the first place, whether he should have exited the race earlier than he did and whether former Vice President Kamala Harris was the right choice to replace him.â€ The audit also wasnâ€™t expected to revisit important Harris campaign decisions, the Times reported, including â€œframing the election as a choice between democracy and fascism, and refraining from hitting back after an ad by Donald J. Trump memorably attacked Ms. Harris on transgender rights.â€

Apparently the DNC was terrified from the outset of any serious reckoning with the many things it got wrong last year. (The Timesâ€™ July article had this great zinger: â€œParty officials described the draft document as focusing on the 2024 election as a whole, but not on the presidential campaign â€” which is something like eating at a steakhouse and then reviewing the salad.â€) It could, of course, be divisive to reconsider the biggest decisions defining the election. But that is precisely the kind of thing a party has to endure when it has record-low approval from its own voters and voters have handed the keys to the republic over to a narcissistic and self-enriching demagogue for a second time. 

We donâ€™t know what the unpublished report ended up concluding, but the Times reported Thursday that the â€œprescriptions were more tactical than strategic,â€ citing DNC officialsâ€™ summary of the findings. Among other things, the audit reportedly questioned the efficacy of peer-to-peer text messaging in influencing voters, as well as door-knocking quotas. This is an entirely different universe of self-scrutiny than the reflections suggested by those of us who have long argued that the party had no real policy vision or that Bidenâ€™s age was a threat to his candidacy.

To be sure, a party autopsy wouldnâ€™t preclude future mistakes. And the reality is that a strong Democratic candidate could disregard its lessons and still win, as President Donald Trump did in 2016.

Still, the fact that the DNC is mothballing whatever audit it could bring itself to conduct underscores that the party remains petrified of its own reflection. The document might have been weak sauce, but releasing it would have at least created a record of how the party viewed itself and laid out the parameters of how the establishment was and wasnâ€™t willing to change to meet the challenges of our era. It would have become a potential source of accountability â€” even if primarily through criticism from progressives in and outside the party about how the self-assessment didnâ€™t go far enough. 

The Democratic establishment, trying to save face, is sweeping some hard truths under the rug. Doing so all but ensures that it wonâ€™t evolve into a party worthy of the countryâ€™s trust.

This was not an ideological earthquake. New York did not suddenly â€œdiscoverâ€ socialism. What happened was a marketing and mobilization breakthrough. Mamdaniâ€™s campaign understood attention, simplicity, participation, and distribution better than anyone else in the race.

Republicans often confuse seriousness with stiffness. Mamdani showed that message discipline does not require lifelessness.

Joe Perello, the city of New Yorkâ€™s first chief marketing officer, noted in PRWeek after Mamdaniâ€™s victory that the campaign did more than communicate a message. It built an engine that converted online engagement into real-world turnout.

â€œFor marketers and strategists alike, the implications are clear,â€ Perello wrote. â€œGrowth hacking, iterative testing, and data-driven amplification can convert digital sentiment into real-world behavior. In Mamdaniâ€™s case, that meant converting hearts, clicks, and hashtags into ballots.â€

Here is the part many on the right do not want to hear: Mamdani did not spend his time lecturing working-class voters about the virtues of socialism or defending failed economic theory. He focused on immediate, kitchen-table concerns and paired them with simple, slogan-ready answers.

Is halal food expensive? Make it cheaper. Struggling to get to work? Free buses. Grocery bills too high? Government-run grocery stores.

He took Bernie Sandersâ€™ 2016-era talking points and filtered them through a polished, Obama-style optimism that voting-age New Yorkers were willing to engage with.

Most voters do not have the time â€” or patience â€” to think through how these promises would actually work. They just want to hear that someone intends to make their lives easier.

Republicansâ€™ digital blind spot

For years, Republican campaigns have treated digital media as messaging rather than infrastructure. Social platforms are used as megaphones for press releases, fundraising tools, or dumping grounds for cable-news clips. The underlying assumption is that persuasion happens elsewhere â€” on TV, at rallies, through mailers â€” and that digital simply amplifies those efforts.

Disagree with his ideology. But study his marketing. Ignore the lesson at your own risk.
